articles.headline: In Europe, Weathering Credit Storm From U.S.
articles.snippet: Jolting announcements from CIFG Holdings and Swiss Re  are stoking fears that Europe will suffer more of the credit ills that have plagued major banks in the United States.
articles.abstract: Jolting announcements from CIFG Holdings and Swiss Re  are stoking fears that Europe will suffer more of the credit ills that have plagued major banks in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Nov. 23 — The American mortgage crisis continues to infect Europe’s financial system in new and unexpected places.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Strategies to Avoid Medicare’s Big Hole
articles.snippet: A gap in Medicare’s prescription drug coverage is helping to curb growth in the nation’s drug spending by pushing people toward low-cost generic drugs.
articles.abstract: A gap in Medicare’s prescription drug coverage is helping to curb growth in the nation’s drug spending by pushing people toward low-cost generic drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Medicare doughnut hole is the federal provision that older Americans love to hate.

articles.headline: Bargain Hunting on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Investors leapt into the ailing stock market, snapping up discounted shares of financial companies that had been battered by shake-ups and write-downs tied to subprime mortgages.
articles.abstract: Investors leapt into the ailing stock market, snapping up discounted shares of financial companies that had been battered by shake-ups and write-downs tied to subprime mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Holiday shoppers weren’t the only ones seeking bargains yesterday.

articles.headline: Bomb at a Market Shatters Lull for Baghdad
articles.snippet: An attack killed eight at a site that had seemed safe last week, providing a cruel reminder that a decline in violence may not last.
articles.abstract: An attack killed eight at a site that had seemed safe last week, providing a cruel reminder that a decline in violence may not last.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Nov. 23 — Last Friday, the Ghazil animal market was a crowded bazaar in a city willing itself into recovery. Cautious but hopeful parents led fun-starved children by the hand to show them parakeets, tropical fish and twittering chicks painted in bright, improbable hues.

articles.headline: Bargains Draw Crowds, but the Thrill Is Gone
articles.snippet: Shoppers favored discounted chains over more expensive retailers as an uncertain economy hung over their heads.
articles.abstract: Shoppers favored discounted chains over more expensive retailers as an uncertain economy hung over their heads.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers flooded stores yesterday on the traditional first day of the holiday shopping season, but the irrational exuberance of the Black Fridays of the last five years has been replaced by pragmatic restraint.

articles.headline: Far From Beijing’s Reach, Officials Bend Energy Rules
articles.snippet: When the Chinese government announced a campaign to cut energy use two years ago, some local officials got to work: not to comply, but to devise schemes to evade the requirements.
articles.abstract: When the Chinese government announced a campaign to cut energy use two years ago, some local officials got to work: not to comply, but to devise schemes to evade the requirements.
articles.lead_paragraph: QINGTONGXIA, China — When the central government in Beijing announced an ambitious nationwide campaign to reduce energy consumption two years ago, officials in this western regional capital got right to work: not to comply, but to engineer creative schemes to evade the requirements.

articles.headline: Saudis to Join Mideast Talks; Syria Wavers
articles.snippet: At least 15 Arab states, including Saudi Arabia, said they would attend a U.S.-sponsored conference.
articles.abstract: At least 15 Arab states, including Saudi Arabia, said they would attend a U.S.-sponsored conference.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Nov. 23 — Saudi Arabia joined 14 other Arab nations on Friday in an agreement to attend the American-sponsored Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md., next week, while Syria — the last key holdout — was inching closer toward agreeing to participate.
articles.byline: By Mona El-Naggar and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Bland Menu if Cable Goes à la Carte
articles.snippet: As appealing as à la carte cable may sound, there is a reason that Congress has not taken the bait: it would be a consumer disaster.
articles.abstract: As appealing as à la carte cable may sound, there is a reason that Congress has not taken the bait: it would be a consumer disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twice in the last few months, I’ve written columns about the bitter “carriage dispute” between the NFL Network and the nation’s two largest cable companies, Comcast and Time Warner. This column, I swear, is not going to be the third in a series. As annoyed as I remain over the tactics of the National Football League, I’ve had my say.

articles.headline: Icy Rescue as Seas Claim a Cruise Ship
articles.snippet: In a lecture hall, passengers were told that the Antarctic waters were creeping in. Then the power failed and the ship ceased responding.
articles.abstract: In a lecture hall, passengers were told that the Antarctic waters were creeping in. Then the power failed and the ship ceased responding.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were modern adventure travelers, following the doomed route of Sir Ernest Shackleton to the frozen ends of the earth. They paid $7,000 to $16,000 to cruise on a ship that had proudly plowed the Antarctic for 40 years.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Andrew C. Revkin

articles.headline: Publisher Gets Web Readers to Fill the Pages of Its Magazines
articles.snippet: A funny thing happened while Halsey Minor, the founder of CNet.com, was trying to kill print journalism. He ended up publishing magazines  - the kind he and others had declared obsolete.
articles.abstract: A funny thing happened while Halsey Minor, the founder of CNet.com, was trying to kill print journalism. He ended up publishing magazines  - the kind he and others had declared obsolete.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 — A funny thing happened while Halsey Minor was trying to kill print journalism. He ended up publishing magazines — big, heavy magazines, with beautiful pictures on quality paper — the kind he and others had declared obsolete.

articles.headline: As Democrats See Security Gains in Iraq, Tone Shifts
articles.snippet: Presidential candidates are trying to shift the focus to a lack of political progress.
articles.abstract: Presidential candidates are trying to shift the focus to a lack of political progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: As violence declines in Baghdad, the leading Democratic presidential candidates are undertaking a new and challenging balancing act on Iraq: acknowledging that success, trying to shift the focus to the lack of political progress there, and highlighting more domestic concerns like health care and the economy.

articles.headline: Blame the Borrowers? Not So Fast
articles.snippet: Many subprime borrowers with fixed-rate loans are doing fine.
articles.abstract: Many subprime borrowers with fixed-rate loans are doing fine.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT has become fashionable of late to say that America’s subprime borrowers themselves deserve a good part of the blame for the current mortgage mess. They were either greedy (looking for easy money in a bubbly real estate market) or irresponsible (assuming a debt whose terms they did not understand).

articles.headline: Farmyard Stills Quench a Thirst for Local Spirits
articles.snippet: On the heels of the microbrewing boom, new microdistilleries are thriving from coast to coast.
articles.abstract: On the heels of the microbrewing boom, new microdistilleries are thriving from coast to coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATCHISON, Kan. — The main still of the High Plains liquor company here was scraped together from junked parts of an old food processing plant. The tubing for the bottling equipment had been used to milk cows, and one of the tanks was actually an industrial vacuum cleaner.

articles.headline: DNA Tests Find Branches but Few Roots
articles.snippet: Scientists and scholars question the claims of companies offering DNA tests to people exploring their ancestry.
articles.abstract: Scientists and scholars question the claims of companies offering DNA tests to people exploring their ancestry.
articles.lead_paragraph: HENRY LOUIS GATES JR., whose PBS special “African American Lives” explores the ancestry of famous African-Americans using DNA testing, has done more than anyone to help popularize such tests and companies that offer them. But recently this Harvard professor has become one of the industry’s critics.

articles.headline: Amateurs Unravel Russia’s Last Royal Mystery
articles.snippet: A discovery may have finally put to rest rumors that two of the children of Czar Nicholas II had escaped execution.
articles.abstract: A discovery may have finally put to rest rumors that two of the children of Czar Nicholas II had escaped execution.
articles.lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — On the outskirts of this burly industrial center, off a road like any other, on a nowhere scrap of land — here unfolded the final act of one of the last century’s most momentous events.

articles.headline: Payload: Taking Aim at Corporate Bribery
articles.snippet: A probe of a British military contractor is but one in a bounty of investigations recently started under a once-obscure anticorruption law.
articles.abstract: A probe of a British military contractor is but one in a bounty of investigations recently started under a once-obscure anticorruption law.
articles.lead_paragraph: LATE last month, five jumbo jets from Riyadh touched down at Heathrow Airport in London. They brought with them 13 members of the Saudi royal family, including King Abdullah and his retainers — and controversy. Over the last four years, the British government has been dogged by criticism of its relationship with Saudi Arabia, which is Britain’s biggest trading partner in the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Lowell Bergman

articles.headline: Vindicated by DNA, but a Lost Man on the Outside
articles.snippet: Exonerated after 16 years in prison, Jeffrey Mark Deskovic is a free man who has yet to feel truly free.
articles.abstract: Exonerated after 16 years in prison, Jeffrey Mark Deskovic is a free man who has yet to feel truly free.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a boy, Jeffrey Mark Deskovic could swim the length of a pool underwater without coming up for air. On sultry days at the Elmira state prison, where he spent most of his 16 years behind bars for a rape and murder he did not commit, Mr. Deskovic would close his eyes under a row of outdoor showers and imagine himself swimming.

articles.headline: Dueling Guitars in Gameland: MTV and Activision Face Off
articles.snippet: One of the most watched rivalries in the video game business is between two games that put players in the role of rock musicians.
articles.abstract: One of the most watched rivalries in the video game business is between two games that put players in the role of rock musicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The holiday season is when all the action takes place in the video game business, and this year has already pitted Microsoft’s Xbox 360 against Sony’s PlayStation 3, and sleek new software against sequels like Halo 3.

articles.headline: Short of Funds, G.O.P. Recruits the Rich to Run
articles.snippet: Confronting a fund-raising gap with Democrats, the Republican Party is recruiting candidates who can spend their own money on Congressional races.
articles.abstract: Confronting a fund-raising gap with Democrats, the Republican Party is recruiting candidates who can spend their own money on Congressional races.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — Confronting an enormous fund-raising gap with Democrats, Republican Party officials are aggressively recruiting wealthy candidates who can spend large sums of their own money to finance their Congressional races, party officials say.

articles.headline: Laugh Lines in the Hollywood Strike
articles.snippet: It turns out, many union members say, that striking in Hollywood — at least short term — is not that bad.
articles.abstract: It turns out, many union members say, that striking in Hollywood — at least short term — is not that bad.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 — When the 12,000 members of the Writers Guild of America decided on Nov. 4 to strike, Hollywood wondered how hard the white-collar group would fight. The guild addressed the worry before the first pickets hit the streets.

articles.headline: Bitterest Rival of Musharraf Returns Home
articles.snippet: The return of Nawaz Sharif is likely to create an immediate and profound change in the political situation in Pakistan.
articles.abstract: The return of Nawaz Sharif is likely to create an immediate and profound change in the political situation in Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 25 — Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived home from exile to a tumultuous welcome on Sunday evening, providing a new rallying point for Pakistan’s disillusioned opposition and setting the stage for an overnight shift of the political scene in the country.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Chief Seeks Votes to Tighten Cable Rules
articles.snippet: The cable industry heavily lobbied the commission and allies in Congress to kill a proposal that would give the F.C.C. the power to more tightly regulate the industry.
articles.abstract: The cable industry heavily lobbied the commission and allies in Congress to kill a proposal that would give the F.C.C. the power to more tightly regulate the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — The head of the Federal Communications Commission is struggling to find enough support from a majority of the agency’s commissioners to regulate cable television companies more tightly.

articles.headline: A Magazine Challenges the Big Boys
articles.snippet: Amid growing media overload, reading matter piles up at home, but The Week is read.
articles.abstract: Amid growing media overload, reading matter piles up at home, but The Week is read.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a room in our house where time has been stopped. There are no flat-panel TVs, no docking stations for the iPod, and no keyboards save my wife’s accordion. In that room — the quaint description is “living room” — there is a large comfortable chair, a good lamp, and a magazine rack groaning with the fruits of American journalism. Almost every day, I drop a magazine there or a longer newspaper article, with the best intention of getting to it when things slow down a bit.

articles.headline: In West Iowa, Obama’s Man Thinks Locally
articles.snippet: A 29-year-old former marine is hoping a personal touch turns voters into Obama recruiters in essential territory.
articles.abstract: A 29-year-old former marine is hoping a personal touch turns voters into Obama recruiters in essential territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa, Nov. 24 — Rory Steele had bounced along a gravel road that rides like a washboard to get to the farmstead. He stepped across a few rows of soybeans, climbed up the steps of a red Case combine and squeezed into a seat next to Lyle McIntosh, who was circling a field.

articles.headline: Retail Sales Rise, but Stores Relied on Discounts
articles.snippet: The reports suggest that jittery consumers are flocking to rock-bottom prices and to little else — a boon for discount stores but trouble for higher-end chains.
articles.abstract: The reports suggest that jittery consumers are flocking to rock-bottom prices and to little else — a boon for discount stores but trouble for higher-end chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Black Friday was big — but with a big caveat.
